newsitem.title: USA: U.S. West spot power extends gains on outages.
newsitem.headline: U.S. West spot power extends gains on outages.

text.p: News of another power plant outage in the western U.S. Wednesday helped spot electricity prices extend yesterday's gains, market sources said.
A 750 megawatt (MW) unit at the coal-fired Navajo generating station in Page, Ariz., was reportedly shut Tuesday for boiler tube repairs.
That outage followed Sunday's shutdown of a 755 MW unit at the Four Corners coal-fired plant, also due to a tube leak.
There has also been talk of a 330 MW unit at the Colstrip coal-fired power plant in central Montana, that has been down since Monday, but its status could not be confirmed.
Outages of the three units tightened short-term power supplies, and forced some players in the Northwest and Southwest to cover their day-ahead schedulings, traders said.
Firm, peak electricity at the California-Oregon border (COB) for Thursday widened to $12.00-$13.50 a megawatt hour (MWh) from $12.50-13.50 Tuesday.
Firm, off-peak COB deliveries for Thursday were quoted at $7.00-7.50, a slightly tighter range than the $6.50-7.50 heard for Wednesday deliveries.
Firm, peak electricity at Mid-Columbia (Mid-C) for Thursday rose to $11.00-11.75 from $10.50-11.50 Tuesday, while off-peak Mid-C for day-ahead delivery stayed at $6.00-7.00.
Firm, peak Palo Verde (PV) electricity climbed to $14.00-15.00 from Tuesday's $13.50-14.00, while off-peak deliveries held at $7.00-9.00.
Next-day firm, peak power at Four Corners was quoted at $14.00-15.00 from $13.00-14.00 Tuesday, while off-peak remained at $7.00-9.00.
Forward COB and PV values held steady from Tuesday's levels. "They are still in the same narrow ranges," a Northwest trader said.
Firm, peak COB power for the second quarter was quoted at $10.35-10.60 and third quarter $16.55-16.75.
Firm, peak PV electricity for Q2 delivery was assessed at $13.90-14.10 and Q3 at $22.35-22.50.

Temperatures in the Northwest were forecast to average 3 to 6 degrees F above normal through Friday with peak readings in the 30s-40s. Showers are expected to continue across the coast while valley rain and mountain snow were called for in the interior regions.

In the Southwest, temperatures will likely remain 2 to 4 degrees F below normal ahead of the weekend, with day readings reaching the 50-60 degree range. Low pressure in the southeastern part of the region could cause precipitation through early Thursday.

Separately, swing gas prices at the Sumas export point on the U.S.-Canada border firmed 25 cents to the $2.15 per million British thermal unit level and those at the Permain Basin area in the Southwest held at $2.24-$2.28.
